articles.headline: When Shareholder Democracy Is Sham Democracy
articles.snippet: There are 41 publicly traded companies with directors who lost their elections last year. Despite these votes of no confidence, they stayed in their posts.
articles.abstract: There are 41 publicly traded companies with directors who lost their elections last year. Despite these votes of no confidence, they stayed in their posts.
articles.lead_paragraph: Two weeks ago, I argued that it was hard to imagine a more compelling case for ousting directors than the one posed by Hewlett-Packard.

articles.headline: J.C. Penney Wins Ruling in Dispute With Macy’s

articles.abstract: A judge says the retailer can at least temporarily sell housewares designed by Martha Stewart under the JCP Everyday label.
articles.lead_paragraph: With Ron Johnson out, Martha Stewart is in at J. C. Penney, at least for the moment.

articles.headline: F.D.A. Issues Warning on Workout Supplement
articles.snippet: The Food and Drug Administration says DMAA, a stimulant used in products like Jack3d, does not qualify as a legal dietary supplement and can cause health problems.
articles.abstract: The Food and Drug Administration says DMAA, a stimulant used in products like Jack3d, does not qualify as a legal dietary supplement and can cause health problems.
articles.lead_paragraph: Certain workout-booster and fat-burning products, sold in recent years by retailers like GNC and Vitamin Shoppe, are illegal and may present serious health hazards to consumers, federal health regulators have determined.
articles.byline: By Natasha Singer and Peter Lattman

articles.headline: Signs of Easier Money for Mortgages
articles.snippet: There are signs that some lenders and mortgage insurers are beginning to loosen eligibility requirements since the days immediately after the housing bubble burst.
articles.abstract: There are signs that some lenders and mortgage insurers are beginning to loosen eligibility requirements since the days immediately after the housing bubble burst.
articles.lead_paragraph: What was so unusual about Phillip Ratliff’s experience in getting approval for his first mortgage was that it wasn’t difficult at all — even though he could afford a down payment of only 5 percent.

articles.headline: Drop in Home Loans Takes Toll on Banks

articles.headline: A Revered French Winery Breaks With a Bordeaux Tradition
articles.snippet: Château Latour is stirring tensions with a decision to stop selling its wines through middlemen in an attempt to hold more profit for itself.
articles.abstract: Château Latour is stirring tensions with a decision to stop selling its wines through middlemen in an attempt to hold more profit for itself.
articles.lead_paragraph: PAUILLAC, France — As they have every April for decades, wine merchants from around the world donned their tweed jackets, tucked in their pocket squares and descended on Bordeaux this week to assess the latest vintage. In visits to revered chateaus in localities like Pomerol, Margaux and Saint-Estèphe, they swirled, sniffed, spat and scored the 2012 Bordeaux.

articles.headline: Steely Leader of South Korea Is Battle-Ready
articles.snippet: As the crisis with North Korea escalates, critics and supporters alike wonder if President Park Geun-hye may have gone too far in presenting herself as an ultra-tough leader.
articles.abstract: As the crisis with North Korea escalates, critics and supporters alike wonder if President Park Geun-hye may have gone too far in presenting herself as an ultra-tough leader.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — Her mother was shot by an assassin. Her father, a staunchly anti-Communist dictator, was similarly killed. And she survived a vicious razor attack to the face.

articles.headline: Tasting Good Life, Opposition in Zimbabwe Slips Off Pedestal
articles.snippet: As long-awaited elections approach, faith is slipping in Morgan Tsvangirai’s Movement for Democratic Change, which now governs alongside President Robert Mugabe.
articles.abstract: As long-awaited elections approach, faith is slipping in Morgan Tsvangirai’s Movement for Democratic Change, which now governs alongside President Robert Mugabe.
articles.lead_paragraph: HARARE, Zimbabwe — The guests arrived in Bentleys, Benzes and BMWs. At a plush, riverside wedding in an upscale suburb, the wine and spirits flowed and tables groaned with the ample buffet. Politicians, celebrities, diplomats and business leaders mingled to the strains of Oliver Mtukudzi, a Zimbabwean music star, serenading the happy couple with his famous love song “Svovi Yangu.”

articles.headline: Kerry in China to Seek Help in Korea Crisis

articles.headline: Note to New S.E.C. Chief: The Clock Is Ticking
articles.snippet: For a lot of cases involving questionable practices and disclosures arising from the mortgage bust of 2008, time is running out.
articles.abstract: For a lot of cases involving questionable practices and disclosures arising from the mortgage bust of 2008, time is running out.
articles.lead_paragraph: AFTER receiving unanimous support from the United States Senate, Mary Jo White was confirmed last week as the new head of the Securities and Exchange Commission. At her swearing-in, she praised S.E.C. officials for “vigorously enforcing the securities laws.”

articles.headline: A Missionary’s Quest to Remake Motor City
articles.snippet: Against tall odds, Dan Gilbert, the Quicken Loans chairman, is putting down money to revive a two-square-mile area that was once Detroit’s core.
articles.abstract: Against tall odds, Dan Gilbert, the Quicken Loans chairman, is putting down money to revive a two-square-mile area that was once Detroit’s core.
articles.lead_paragraph: THE best way to experience all that is strange and a little otherworldly about downtown Detroit is to walk the streets around 5 p.m. on a weekday. At that hour, you’ll notice not just the peculiarity of what is around you — notably, the gorgeous, Art Deco skyscrapers alongside empty, decrepit buildings — but also what is missing. There is no traffic here. As the workday ends, cars trickle out of underground parking lots and speed off to nearby highways, but in a volume that doesn’t cause delays.

articles.headline: Sometimes, We Want Prices to Fool Us
articles.snippet: Because of the quirks of human psychology, simplifying pricing isn’t so simple. J.C. Penney learned that lesson the hard way.
articles.abstract: Because of the quirks of human psychology, simplifying pricing isn’t so simple. J.C. Penney learned that lesson the hard way.
articles.lead_paragraph: WHEN the board of J. C. Penney ousted its chief executive, Ron Johnson — news that broke last Monday — you might say it was, in some small way, because he didn’t understand Tracie Fobes.
articles.byline: By Stephanie Clifford and Catherine Rampell

articles.headline: Conduct at Issue as Military Officers Face a New Review
articles.snippet: The American military for the first time will require generals and admirals to be evaluated by the people they command on qualities including character.
articles.abstract: The American military for the first time will require generals and admirals to be evaluated by the people they command on qualities including character.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — After a series of scandals involving high-ranking officers, the American military for the first time will require generals and admirals to be evaluated by their peers and the people they command on qualities including personal character.

articles.headline: Obama’s Budget Revives Benefits as Divisive Issue
articles.snippet: President Obama’s proposal to trim future Medicare and Social Security benefits as part of a deficit compromise could force Democrats to take an uncomfortable stand on a measure that is unpopular with their base.
articles.abstract: President Obama’s proposal to trim future Medicare and Social Security benefits as part of a deficit compromise could force Democrats to take an uncomfortable stand on a measure that is unpopular with their base.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Whether or not Republicans ever agree to a budget deal with President Obama, one thing seems certain: now that he has officially put Social Security and Medicare benefits on the negotiating table, opponents on his party’s left will make that an issue for Democrats in the midterm elections next year — and perhaps in the 2016 presidential contest.

articles.headline: Shy No More, N.R.A.’s Top Gun Sticks to Cause
articles.snippet: Wayne LaPierre, the chief executive of the National Rifle Association, has honed a no-compromise strategy over the last 35 years that is now facing its most difficult test in decades.
articles.abstract: Wayne LaPierre, the chief executive of the National Rifle Association, has honed a no-compromise strategy over the last 35 years that is now facing its most difficult test in decades.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Victims of the massacre in Newtown, Conn., had just been laid to rest when Wayne LaPierre, the chief executive of the National Rifle Association, met with his board of directors in early January. A national tide of grief had prompted new attacks on his group and a White House push for more gun control measures, while Mr. LaPierre — who had called for armed guards in every school — was pilloried as a “gun nut” on the cover of The New York Post.
articles.byline: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg and Jodi Kantor

articles.headline: Losing a Step, Nike Seeks to Regain Its Edge

articles.lead_paragraph: Lost in the middle of a debate last month over a Nike ad that congratulated Tiger Woods for regaining his ranking as the world’s No. 1 golfer was that people were talking about a Nike ad.

articles.headline: More Cracks Undermine the Citadel of TV Profits
articles.snippet: Television has thrived on bundling, which offers a way of protecting things but also tends to obscure the weaknesses within. Now those flaws are becoming more apparent.
articles.abstract: Television has thrived on bundling, which offers a way of protecting things but also tends to obscure the weaknesses within. Now those flaws are becoming more apparent.
articles.lead_paragraph: For the longest time in the media business, the concept of the bundle has been foundational. Ads go with editorial content in print, commercials go with programming on television and the channels you desire are paired with ones you did not in your cable package.

articles.headline: Intel Tries to Secure Its Footing Beyond PCs
articles.snippet: The world’s largest semiconductor maker is struggling to adapt as PC sales collapse, users rely more on mobile phones and tablets, and cloud computing expands.
articles.abstract: The world’s largest semiconductor maker is struggling to adapt as PC sales collapse, users rely more on mobile phones and tablets, and cloud computing expands.
articles.lead_paragraph: SANTA CLARA, Calif. — For the last several months, Andy Bryant, the chairman of Intel, has been trying to put steel in the backs of the company’s employees. At meetings, he tells them that Intel must fundamentally change even though the computer chip maker still has what it takes to succeed in engineering and manufacturing.

articles.headline: Venezuela Gives Chávez Protégé Narrow Victory
articles.snippet: Nicolás Maduro, the handpicked protégé of Hugo Chávez, won an unexpectedly close race for the presidency. His rival demanded a recount.
articles.abstract: Nicolás Maduro, the handpicked protégé of Hugo Chávez, won an unexpectedly close race for the presidency. His rival demanded a recount.
articles.lead_paragraph: CARACAS, Venezuela — In an unexpectedly close race, Venezuelans narrowly voted to continue Hugo Chávez’s revolution, electing his handpicked political heir, Nicolás Maduro, to serve the remainder of his six-year term as president, officials said late Sunday.

articles.headline: Europeans Reach Deal With Google on Searches
articles.snippet: Google has for the first time agreed to legally binding changes to its search results after an antitrust investigation by European regulators.
articles.abstract: Google has for the first time agreed to legally binding changes to its search results after an antitrust investigation by European regulators.
articles.lead_paragraph: Google has for the first time agreed to legally binding changes to its search results after an antitrust investigation by European regulators into whether it abuses its dominance of online search.

articles.headline: Parties’ Rifts Hinder Background Check Measure in Gun Bill
articles.snippet: Divisions over a measure to extend background checks for gun buyers are undermining support for what was seen as a compromise deal to ease passage of a broader bill.
articles.abstract: Divisions over a measure to extend background checks for gun buyers are undermining support for what was seen as a compromise deal to ease passage of a broader bill.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Deep divisions within both parties over a bipartisan measure to extend background checks for gun buyers are threatening its chances as the Senate this week begins debating the first broad gun control legislation in nearly 20 years.
articles.byline: By Jennifer Steinhauer and Jonathan Weisman

articles.headline: Hedge Fund Titans’ Pay Stretching to 10 Figures
articles.snippet: A number of the hedge fund leaders who had giant paydays last year earned their riches the old-fashioned way: by posting big returns on their investments.
articles.abstract: A number of the hedge fund leaders who had giant paydays last year earned their riches the old-fashioned way: by posting big returns on their investments.
articles.lead_paragraph: In recent years, the criticism about giant Wall Street hedge funds — those that command billions of investor dollars from pension funds, endowments and the wealthy — is that they’re simply too big to beat the market.
